questiontext.text: In times of rising prices, what will be the effect upon profit and closing inventory valuation using the first in, first out method of inventory valuation in comparison to the average cost method of inventory valuation?

generalfeedback.text: With FIFO, closing inventory is the most recently purchased items, therefore when prices are rising, closing inventory will have a higher value than if the average cost method of inventory valuation is used. Since closing inventories will be valued higher, the cost of sales will be lower and the profit will be higher.

answer.text: A higher profit and a lower closing inventory value
A higher profit and a higher closing inventory value
A lower profit and a lower closing inventory value
A lower profit and a higher inventory value

Dani uses the continuous weighted average cost method of inventory valuation. At 1 April 20X9 Dani had 50 units in inventory at a total value of $815. The inventory movements during February 20X4 were as follows:
Receipts 14-Apr 270 units at $19.50 per unit
Sales 18-Apr 180 units at $35.00 per unit

What was the cost of goods sold by Firdani for the month of April 20X9?

Answer: {2:NUMERICAL:=3420:0}

generalfeedback.text:
Continuous average cost per unit = ($815+= (270 x $19.50))/320 units = $19.00.
Therefore, cost of goods sold = 180 x 180 units = $3,420.

questiontext.text: What is the double-entry to record the value of inventory withdrawn from the business by the proprietor for own use?

generalfeedback.text: This double-entry reflects that fact that some of the purchases made for resale have now been taken by the proprietor for own use, and therefore an increase in drawings is also recorded.

answer.text: Debit Drawings, and Credit Capital
Debit Purchases, and Credit Drawings
Debit Inventory (Statement of FP), and Credit Inventory (Statement of P&L)
Debit Drawings, and Credit Purchases

questiontext.text:
During the process to prepare the final accounts, the proprietor identified that several items of closing inventory had been valued incorrectly. A cost of $100 per unit had been used, rather than the correct cost of $70 per unit.
What accounting entries are required to correct this error?

generalfeedback.text: The error has resulted in closing inventory (a debit balance in the statement of financial position) being overstated, with a corresponding overstatement in the credit entry made in the statement of profit or loss. Therefore, to correct this error, it requires a credit entry to Closing inventory (Statement of FP) to reduce the value of the inventory asset in the statement of financial position and a debit entry in the inventory account in the statement of P&L. The latter accounting entry has the effect of reducing the credit relating to closing inventory in the statement of P&L.

answer.text: Debit Inventory (Statement of P&L), and Credit Purchases
Debit Inventory (Statement of P&L), and Credit Inventory (Statement of FP)
Debit Inventory (Statement of FP), and Credit Inventory (Statement of P&L)
Debit Purchases (Statement of FP), and Credit Inventory
